projectDesc.p: The Middle English Texts Series offers a diverse and representative array of literary texts that medieval readers in the present-day British Isles would have encountered between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries. It is committed to making available both affordable print and open access editions to scholars, teachers, and students of the Western Middle Ages. In its digital publications, the series prioritizes a user-friendly interface and viewing options, multiple downloadable formats, enhanced searchability and filtering, and accessibility to the widest possible range of users.

editorialDecl.p: METS takes as its mission the creation of affordable editions that would pass scrutiny from the most demanding expert, yet would prove comprehensible, and even enticing, to someone who had never read Middle English before. This agenda dictates that METS publications offer not a critical edition reflecting all surviving manuscripts, and certainly not a diplomatic edition, but a best-text edition, informed by the notes and apparatus of earlier editions (where these exist), and by substantive variants from other manuscript witnesses. Transcriptions of Middle English texts are lightly modernized to ensure a smooth reading experience, while non-English texts preserve both the original language and a modern English translation in facing-page format. Each edition offers expert assistance with language and lexicon, providing glosses alongside the text(s), textual and explanatory notes, elucidation of unfamiliar contexts and traditions, and thematic and interpretive possibilities. All editions feature general introductions that set the edited text within its own time, place, and traditions, and link it to ancestor, congener, and successor materials. All publications contain comprehensive, current bibliographies of pertinent scholarship and criticism. House style is adapted from the Chicago Manual of Style.

lg.l: AtT SevordeN T seteT theynes monye,
Fele biscopes,and feole bok-ilered,T
Eorles prute,knyhtes egleche.
Thar wes the Eorl Alvrich,N
Of thare lawe swithe wis,
And ek Ealvred,Englene hurde,
Englene durlyngT —
On Englene londeN T he wes kyng.
Heom he bigon lere,T
So ye mawe ihure,
HwT hi heore liflede scholden.
Alvred he wes in Englene londT
AndT king wel swithe strong.
He wes king and he wes clerek.N T
Wel he luvede Godes werk.
He wes wis on his word,and war on his werke.
He wes the wysuste mon
That wes Englelonde on.T
ThusT queth Alvred,Englene frouer:
“Wolde ye, mi leode,lusten eureT louerde;
He ouT wolde wyssyewisliche thinges:
HwT ye myhte worldeswrthsipesT welde,
And ek eure saulesomnen to Criste.”
Wyse were the wordesthe seyde the King Alvred.T
fol. 189v“MildelicheTT ich munye,myne leove freond,
Poure and riche,leode myne,
That ye alle adredeT ure Dryhten Crist.
Luvyen hine and lykyen,for he is Louerd of Lyf;
He is one godover alle godnesse;
He is one gleawover alle glednesse;
He is one blisseover alle blissen;
He is one monne,mildest mayster;
He is one folkes fader,and frouer;
He is one rihtwis,and so riche king
That him ne schal beo wonenouht of his wille,
TheT hine her on worldewrthieT thencheth.”N T
ThusT queth Alvred,Englene vrouer:
“Ne may non ryhtwis kingunderT Criste seolvenN
Bute if he beoin boke ilered,
And he his wyttesT swithe wel kunne,
And he cunne lettreslokie himseolf oneN
HwT he schule his londlaweliche holde.”N
“TheT eorl and theT ethelyng
Ibureth, under godneT king,
That lond to leden
Myd lawelyche deden.
And the clerekT and the knyht
He schulleT demenT evelycheT riht,
The poure and the ryche
DemenT ilyche.
Hwych so the mon soweth,
Al swuch he schal mowe;N
And everuyches monnes domto his owere dure churreth.N
Than knyhte bihovethkenlicheT on to foneT
For to werie that londwith hunger and with heriunge,
That the ChirecheT habbe gryth,
And the cheorl beo in fryth
His sedes to sowen,
His medes to mowen,N
And his plouh beo idryve.
To ure alre bihove
This is thes knyhtes lawe.N Loke he that hit wel fare.”N T T
ThusT queth Alvred:
“The mon the on his youhtheyeorne leorneth
Wit and wisdom,and iwriten reden,
He may beon on eldewenliche lortheu;N T
And the that nule oneT youhtheyeorne leorny
Wit and wysdom,and iwriten rede,
That him schal on eldesore rewe.
Thenne cumeth elde,
And unhelthe,
Thenne beoth his weneT
Ful wrotheN isene;
Bothe heo beoth biswikeand eke hi beoth aswunde.”
Thus queth Alvred.T
“WythuteT wysdome,is weole wel unwurth,
For they o mon ahtehuntseventiN acres,
And he hi hadde isowenalle myd reade golde,
fol. 190rAnd that gold greoweso gres doth on eorthe,
Nere he, for his weole,never the further
Bute he him, of frumthe,T freond iwrche,T
For hwat is gold bute ston
Bute if hit haveth wis mon?”N N
“NeT scolde never yong monhowyenN to swithe,
Theih him his wysewel ne lykie,
Ne theih he ne weldeal that he wolde,
For God may yeve,thenne he wule,
God after uvele,weole after wowe.T
Wel is him that hitischapen is.”T
“StrongT hit is to reoweT ayeyn the seeT that floweth,
So hit is to swynkeayeyn unylimpe.
The mon theT on his youhtheswoT swinketh
And worldes weoleher iwinth,
That he may on eldeidelnesse holde,
And ek myd his worldes weole
God iqueme er he quele,
Youthe and al that he haveth idroweN
Is thenne wel bitowe.”N N
“MonyT mon weneththat he wene ne tharf,
Longes lyves,ac him lyeth theT wrench;
For thanne hisT lyvesT alre best luvede,
Thenne he schal letenT lyf his owe.
For nys no wrtT vexyndeT a wude ne a velde
That ever muwe thas feyefurth upholde.N
Not no mon thene tymehwanne he schal heonne turne.
Ne no mon thene endehwenne he schal heonne wende.
Dryhten hit one wot,dowethes Louerd,N
HwanneT ure lifleten schule.”N
“YfT thu seolver and gold yefstand weldest in this world,
Never upenT eortheto wlonk thu nywrthe.T
Ayhte nys non ildre istreonT ac hit is Godes lone;N
Hwanne hitT is his wille,tharof we schulle wende,
And ure owe lyfmyd alleN forleten.
Thanne schulle ure ifonto ure vouhT gripen,
Welden ure maythenes,N T and leten us byhinde.”N
“NeT ilef thu nouht to feleuppe the seeT that floweth.
If thu hafst madmes,monye and inowe,
Gold and seolver,hit schal gnydeT to nouht;
fol. 190vTo duste hit schal dryven;Dryhten schal libben evere.
Mony mon, for his gold,haveth Godes urre,
And for his seolver,hymseolve
Foryemeth, foryeteth,and forleseth.T
Betere him bycomeiboren that he nere.”T
“LustethT ye, meT leode,
Ower is the neode,
And ich eu will lereT wit and wisdom,that alle thing overgoth.N
Syker he may sittetheT hyne haveth to ivere;
For theyh his eyhte him ago,
His wit ne agoth hym nevermo,
For ne may he forvare
The hyne haveth to vere
The wileT his owe lyfileste mote.”N
“IfT thu havest seorewe,
Ne seye thu hit nouhtT than arewe.N
Seye hit thine sadelbowe,and ryd the singinde forth.
Thenne wile wene, thet thine wise ne con,that the thine wise wel lyke.T
Serewe if thu havestand the erewe hit wot,
Byfore he the meneth,
Byhynde he the teleth.
Thu hit myht segge swyhcT mon
That theT ful wel onN —
Wythute echere ore,N
He on the muchele more.
Byhud hit on thire heorte
That the eft ne smeorte;
Ne let thu hyne wite
Al that thin heorte bywite.”N
“NeT schaltu nevere thi wifby hire wlyte cheose,
For never noneT thingethat heo to the bryngeth;
Ac leorne hire custe —heo cutheth hi wel sone.
For mony mon, for ayhte,uvele iauhteth,
And ofte mon, of fayre,frakele icheoseth.
Wo is him that uvel wif
Bryngeth to his cotlyf.
So him is alyve,
That uvele ywyveth
For he schal uppenT eorthe
Dreori iwurthe.N
Mony mon singeth
That wif hom bryngeth;
Wiste he hwat he brouhte,
Wepen he myhte.”N
“NeT wurth thu never so wodne so wyn-drunke
That evereT segge thine wifealle thine wille,
For if thuT iseye the bivorethine ivo alle,
And thu hi myd wordeiwreththed hevedest,
Ne scholde heo hit letefor thing lyvyinde,
That heo ne scholde the forth upbreydeof thine baleusythes.
Wymmon is word-wothT and haveth tunge to swift;
Theyh heo wel wolde,ne may heo hi nowiht welde.”N
fol. 191r“IdelschipeT and overpruteN that lerethyong wif uvele thewes,
And ofte that woldeT
Do that heo ne scholde.
Thene untheu lihte
Leten heo myhte
If heo ofte aswote,T
Forswunke were,
Theyh hit is uvel to buwe
That beo nule treowe,
For ofte museth the katafter hire moder.N
The mon that let wymmonhis mayster iwurthe
Ne schal he never beon ihurd
His wordes louerd;
Ac, heo hine schal steornetotrayen and toteone.N T
And selde wurth he blythe and gled
The mon that is his wives qued.
Mony appel is bryht withuteand bitter withinne;N
So is mony wymmonon hyre fader bure
Schene under schete,N and theyh heo is schendful;
So is mony gedelynggodlyche on horse,
And is theyh lutel wurthN —
Wlonk bi the glede
And uvelT at thare neode.”
“NevreT thu bi thine lyve
The word of thine wyve
To swithe thu ne aredeT
If heo beo iwreththed
Myd worde other myd dede.
Wymmon wepeth for modN
Oftere than for eny god,
And ofte lude and stilleN
For to vordryeN hire wille;
Heo wepeth otherhwile
For to do the gyle.
Salomon hit haveth ised:
‘That wymmon can wel uvelne red.’
The hire red foleweth,
Heo bryngeth hine to seorewe,N
For hit seyth in the lothN T
As ‘cuenesT forteoth.’N
Hit is ifurn iseyd
ThatT ‘cold red is quene red.’N
Hu he is unledeT
That foleweth hire rede.
Ich hit ne segge nouht, forthan,
That god thing ysT god wymmon,
The mon theT hi may icheoseand icovereN over othre.”
“MonyT mon weneththat he weny ne tharf:
Freond that he habbethar me him vayre bihat,
Seyth him vayre bivore,and frakele bihynde;
So me may thane lothelengust lede.
Ne ilef thu never thane mon
That is of feole speche,T
Ne alle the thinge
That thu iherest singe.T
Mony mon haveth swikelne muth,
Milde and monne forcuth;N
Nele he the cuthehwenne he the wule bikache.”N
“ThurhT sawe, mon is wis,
And, thurh hiselthe,N T mon is gleu.
Thurh lesinge, mon is loth,
fol. 191vAnd thurh luthre, wrenches and unwurth;T
And thurh hokede hondeN that he bereth,
Himseolve he forvareth.
From lesynge thu the wune,
And alle unthewes thu the bischune,
So myht thu on theode
Leof beon in alle leode.
And luve thyne nexte —he is at the neode god.T
At chepynge and at chyreche,N T
Freond thu the iwurche
Wyth pouere and with riche,
With alle monne ilyche.
Thanne myht thu sikerlichesely sytte,
And ek faren over londeT hwider so beoth thi wille.”
“AlleT world-ayhte
Schulle bicumen to nouhte,
And uyches cunnes madmesto mixeN schulen imulten;
And ure owe liflutel hwile ileste,
For theyh o monwolde al the worlde
And al the wunnethe tharinne wunyeth,
Ne myhte he, tharmyde, his lifnone hwile holde,
Ac al he schal forletenon a litel stunde;
And schal ure blisseto balewe us iwurthe
Bute if we wurchethwyllen Cristes.
Nu bithenche we, thanne,us sulve,
Ure lif to ledenso Crist us gynneth lere;
Thanne mawe we wenenthat he wule us wrthie.T
For so seyde SalomonT the wise:N
‘The mon that her wel deth
He cumeth thar he lyen foth
On his lyves ende,
He hit schal avynde.’”
“NeT gabbe thu ne schotteN
Ne chid thu wyth none sotte,
Ne myd manyes cunnes tales
Ne chid thu with nenne dwales.
Ne never thu ne bigynneT
To telle thine tythinges
At nones fremannes borde,
Ne have thu to vale worde.
Mid fewe worde wis mon
Fele bilukenN wel con,
And sottes bolt is sone iscohte.N T
Forthi ich holde hine for dote
That sayth al his wille
Thanne he scholde beon stille,
For ofte tunge breketh bon
Theyh heo seolf nabbe non.”N
“WisT child is
Fader blisse.N
If hit so bitydeththat thu bern ibidest,
The hwile hit is lutel,ler him mon thewes;N
fol. 192rThanne hit is wexynde,hit schal wende tharto:
The betere hit schal iwurthe
Ever buven eorthe.N
Ac if thu him lest weldewexendeN T on worlde,
Lude and stille
His owene wille.
Hwanne cumeth ealde,
Ne myht thu hyne awelde.
Thanne deth hit sone
That the bith unyqueme;T
Oferhoweth thin ibod,
And maketh the ofte sory-mod.
Betere the were
Iboren that he nere,
For betere is child unborethane unbuhsum.N
The mon the spareth yeordeand yonge childe,
And let hit arixlye,N T that he hit areche ne may,
That him schal, on ealde,sore reowe.”N Amen.

p.l: fol. 189rHere begin the proverbs of King Alfred.

lg.l: At Sheffordsat many thanes,
Many bishops,and many book-learned,
Proud earls,brave knights.
There was Earl Alfrich,
So wise in their law,
And also Alfred,shepherd of the English,
Beloved by the English —
Of the land of the Englishhe was king.
He taught them,
As you may hear,
How their lives theyought to lead.
Alfred was in the land of the English
A very powerful king.
He was king and he was scholar.
Well did he love God’s work.
He was wise in word,and careful in work.
He was the wisest man
In England.
Thus says Alfred,comforter of the English:
“Be willing, my people,to listen to your lord;
He wishes to teach youwise things:
How you might worldlyhonor possess,
And also your souljoin to Christ.”
Wise were the wordsthen said by King Alfred.
fol. 189v“Mildly do I admonish,my dear friends,
Poor and rich,my people,
That all of you should fearour Lord Christ.
Love and please him,for he is Lord of Life;
He is the one goodover all goodness;
He is the one joyover all joyfulness;
He is the one blissover all blissfulness;
He is the one man,mildest master;
He is the one father of folk,and source of comfort;
He is the one justice,and so powerful a king
That he shall lack nothingof what he desires,
Who here in this worldintends to honor him.”
Thus says Alfred,comforter of the English:
“There can be no just kingunder Christ himself
Unless he belearned in books,
And able to usehis intelligence,
And can read lettersto examine on his own
How his land he shouldmaintain lawfully.”
“The earl and the noble atheling
Are obliged, under a good king,
To lead the land
With lawful deed.
And they must fairly judge
The clerk and the knight,
Judge even-handedly
The poor and the rich.
What a man sows,
So must he reap;
And every man’s judgmentreturns to his own door.
The knight is obligedto bravely undertake
To defend the landfrom hunger and invasion,
So the Church has protection,
And the peasant in the field
May sow his seeds,
Mow his meadows,
And drive his plow.
We all ought to know
This is the knight’s duty.He must see that it goes well.”
“He who in his youtheagerly learns
Wit and wisdom,and reads what’s written,
In old age he may bean excellent teacher;
And he who in youth refusesto eagerly learn
Wit and wisdom,and read what’s written,
In old age he shallsorely regret it.
When old age comes,
And ill health,
Then is his opinion
Seen to be perverse;
It is both deludedand also feeble.”
“Without wisdom,wealth is worthless,
For even if a man possessedseventy acres,
And had sown themall with red gold,
fol. 190rAnd that gold grewas grass does on earth,
He’d never, for all his wealth,advance any further
Unless he, from the beginning,gains friends for himself,
For what is gold but stone
Unless it’s owned by a wise man?”
“A young man should neverbe overly distressed,
Even if his situationisn’t to his liking,
And he doesn’t controlall he’d like to,
For God may give him,when he will,
Good after bad,happiness after grief.
Well is he who for thatis destined.”
“It’s as difficult to rowagainst the flowing sea,
As to striveagainst misfortune.
The man who in his youthstrives so
And worldly wealthwins here,
So that in old age he maygain leisure,
And also with his worldly wealth
Pleases God before he dies,
Then youth and all he’s earned
Are well applied.”
“Many a man expectswhat he may not expect,
Long length of life,but he’ll be deceived;
For when his lifeis most cherished,
Then shall he losehis own life.
For there’s no herb growingin wood or in field
That can ever sustainwhat’s fated to die.
None knows the timewhen he’ll turn from here.
None knows the destinationwhen he’ll go hence.
Only God knows,Lord of hosts,
When our lifewill end.”
“If silver and gold you giveand wield in this world,
Don’t ever on earthbecome overly proud.
Property’s not gained from parentsbut a loan from God;
When it’s his will,we’ll turn away from it,
And our own lifeentirely lose.
Then our enemies willseize our treasures,
Control our valuables,and leave us behind.”
“Don’t trust too muchin the sea that flows.
If you have treasures,abundant and plentiful,
Gold and silver,it’ll crumble to nothing;
fol. 190vTo dust it’ll be reduced;the Lord will live forever.
Many a man, for his gold,receives God’s wrath,
And for his silver,himself
Neglects, forgets,and loses.
It’d be better for himhad he never been born.”
“Listen, my people,
You are in need,
And I’ll teach you wit and wisdom,beyond all things.
Securely sits hewho has it for company;
For though his property leave him,
His wit may never go from him,
For he cannot perish
Who has it for company
As long as his own lifemay last.”
“If you have sorrow,
Never tell it to a scoundrel.
Tell it to your saddlebow,and ride forth singing.
Then he’ll think, ignorant of your state,that you’re happy.
If you have sorrowand the scoundel knows it,
To your face he’ll comfort you,
Behind your back he’ll mock you.
You may have told it to such a man
As wishes you very well —
Without any mercy,
He’d wish you even more.
Hide it in your heart
So that you’re not hurt again;
Never let him know
What your heart guards.”
“You must never chooseyour wife for her beauty,
No matter whatshe brings to you;
Learn instead her character —she’ll reveal it right away.
For many a man, for wealth,makes a bad bargain,
And often a man, for beauty,chooses what’s worthless.
Woeful is he who brings
A bad wife to his dwelling.
While he’s alive,
The one badly wived
Shall everywhere
Become miserable.
Many a man sings
Who brings home a wife;
If he knew what he brought,
He’d surely weep.”
“Don’t ever be so crazyor so drunk on wine
That you ever tell your wifeall your secrets,
For even if you saw before youall your enemies,
And with your wordshave enraged them,
She’d not neglect,for any living creature,
To upbraid you openlyfor your mistakes.
Woman is word-madand has a very quick tongue;
Even if she wanted to,she can’t control it at all.”
fol. 191r“Indolence and excessive pride teacha young wife bad habits.
And make her often want
To do what she shouldn’t.
She might readily
Avoid bad habits
If she had to sweat often,
Worn out by work,
Though it’s hard to bend
What won’t be straight,
For often a cat learns to mousefrom her mother.
The man who allows a womanto be his master
Will never be listened to
As lord of his words;
Instead, she’ll severelytorment and harass him.
Seldom is a man happy and glad
Who is his wife’s enemy.
Many an apple’s shiny withoutand bitter within;
So is many a womanin her father’s house
Beautiful under sheet,and yet she’s shameless;
So is many a soldierhandsome on a horse,
And yet worth little —
Brave by the hearth
And useless when needed.”
“Don’t ever in your life
Heed too hastily
The advice of your wife
If she’s been angered
By word or by deed.
A woman weeps for wrath
More often than for good,
And under all circumstances
To advance her own will;
She weeps at other times
In order to deceive you.
Solomon has said it:
‘Woman is prone to give bad advice.’
Whoever follows her advice,
She’ll bring him to sorrow,
For it’s said everywhere
That ‘women deceive.’
It’s long been said
That ‘cold counsel is woman’s counsel.’
How miserable is he
Who follows her counsel.
I don’t deny at all, however,
That a good woman is a good thing,
For one who may chooseand win her above others.”
“Many a man thinkswhat he oughtn’t think:
That he has a friendwhen someone makes fair promises,
Says fair things to his face,but evil behind his back;
Thus may someone loath the onehe’s accompanied longest.
Don’t believe any man
Who’s of varying speech,
Nor all of the things
You hear being sung.
Many a man has a deceptive mouth,
A gentle yet wicked man;
He’ll not let you knowwhen he plans to trick you.”
“By proverb, man is wise,
And, by piety, man is good.
By lying, man is loathsome,
fol. 191vAnd by evil, worthless and false;
And by having hooked hands,
He ruins himself.
Lose the habit of lying,
And shun all your vices,
So that everywhere you may
Be beloved by all people.
And love your neighbor —he’s helpful in time of need.
At market and at church,
Acquire friends for yourself
Among poor and rich,
With all men equally.
You will certainly thenbe happily situated,
And also travel over landwherever you want.”
“All worldly wealth
Will come to nothing,
And each kind of treasurewill dwindle to filth;
And our own lifelasts a little while,
For even if a manwanted the whole world
And all the joysdwelling therein,
His life he may not, therewith,keep for a while,
But he must lose allin a brief moment;
And so will our blisslead us to torment
Unless we performChrist’s will.
Now let’s resolve, then,on our own,
To lead our lifeas Christ taught us;
Then may we hopethat he will reward us.
For so said Solomon the wise:
‘The man who does well here
Comes where he’ll be received
At his life’s end,
As he shall find out.’”
“Don’t scoff or yell
Or quarrel with a fool,
Or with all sorts of claims
Argue with dimwits.
You shouldn’t ever begin
To disclose your news
At any franklin’s table,
Nor have too many words.
With few words the wise man
Can express a great deal,
And a fool’s arrow is soon shot.
So I hold him a dolt
Who tells all his private thoughts
When he ought to be quiet,
For often does a tongue break a bone
Though itself has none.”
“Wise child is
Father’s bliss.
If it should happenthat you have a child,
While it is small,teach him good habits;
fol. 192rThen as it grows,it shall carry on that way:
The better it shall become
Of any seen on earth.
But if you fail to control himas he grows in the world,
In all circumstances
He’ll do as he pleases.
When old age advances,
You’ll be unable to manage him.
Then soon it will do
What displeases you;
He disdains your command,
And often causes you grief.
It’d have been better for you
Had he not been born,
For better is an unborn childthan a disobedient one.
The man who spares the rodand the young child,
And allows it to have its own way,and he cannot control it,
That one will, in old age,sorely regret it.” Amen.

trailer.l: Here end the sayings of King Alfred.
